reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Complicated, and wonderful!
reviews.reviewText: Blake has done it again! Awesome! Another terrific story extremely well written! I love a book that I can’t put down and can’t stop thinking about once I do.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book. Although the writing style takes a little getting used to, once you do it's easy to follow. It was great seeing the different scenarios involved in this story. Definitely a must read for anyone who enjoys science fiction.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Couldn’t put it down
reviews.reviewText: This was one of those books that I couldn’t put down once I started reading it. Every time I thought I had it figured out there was another unexpected twist or turn that kept me guessing to right to the end. Definitely worth a read. Or two!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2024
reviews.reviewText: One of my all time favorite books was Dark Matter- I was so excited to read this and it did not disappoint !

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars a thousand lifetimes
reviews.reviewText: If you had the chance to live a thousand lifetimes…the ability to travel back in time and prevent any pain in your life…would you do it? Or would you let your life play out as it was meant to?

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Kinda a Time Travel Mess
reviews.reviewText: Sigh... I wanted to like this book. Writing style is good, the premise of some kind of "memory virus" was really interesting to me... butSPOILERS AHEAD...it really just becomes a time travel thing. 12 monkeys / groundhogs day (30 years) kinda jam. Scientist invents some chair with half baked science stuff with a good heart, but it ends up allowing people to go back in time an change things... but then at a time-point, everyone gets the memories from the alternate time lines. So peoples brains get jammed with multiple timelines of memories.Eventually the tech intended for good gets used for bad and this sets our protagonist(s ?) on a 30 year groundhogs day thing to try and fix it.There's always so many holes you can poke in time travel stuff though. Why does she always wait till its basically the apocalypse and her skin is melting off before almost just barely making the jump back one more time? I mean, she knows its coming - she literally knows the future point - so why not jump back like... a day before the apocalypse? Save some melting skin?Also at a certain point, she knows so much about the world she should just like, I dunno, take it over in that 30 years through wealth and basically knowing everything about the future. That's one way to prevent stereotypical American enemy countries from attacking. Just... take em over? I'm sure there's a way.This groundhogs day thing that is bugging me is only like, the last 5th of the book. Before that it's separated in to somewhat disjointed other parts that feel all over the map.So for me, the logline, the premise pitched for the book is better than what it actually is. It is short and competency written though, so if you are the type that just likes action/sci-fi stuff with little regard for logic, it might be a fun read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I will never look at time or reality the same . So well done! Gotta love Blake Crouch . Such a terrific read .

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A monumentally good read
reviews.reviewText: I have a little time for recreational reading these days. But I am so glad that I chose this book to read.Getting through the first book/chapter I came to the conclusion that it seemed pretty good, but also fairly predictable. Boy was I wrong.It is mind bending, and will stretch your imagination. It is well written, and does not demand large leaps of faith. Things fit together very logically and plausibly.I hope you love it as much as I did.

This was another mind-bending page turner from Blake Crouch, a twist on Dark Matter and Wayward Pines. If you like those ones, get this one! No spoilers here, but Crouch seems to continually push the (time) envelope and keep us guessing: what could possibly go wrong next? Intensely creative mind at work here.
A fantastic storyline ("line"), great characters, I just could not stop reading. This is one of the best sci-fi books I've read.

A scientist builds a machine that allows people to travel to the past, but not through the typical methods you have seem over and over in other books. The author then takes us to a world of diverse and surprising consequences, in a mix of thriller and sci-fi that will keep you on the edge of your seat. 4.5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Just buy it and read it now
reviews.reviewText: It's been a long time since a book managed to leave me with my mouth wide open in disbelief. Several times. I can't begin to describe this one, but I can tell you that it's a crazy page-turner that ended up in my actual dreams and prevented me from sleeping. It basically ruined my life. Now leave me alone, it's 3:28 AM and I'm writing a review. Damn.

Having just finished 'Dark Matter', I was unsure whether to buy 'Recursion', as some of the reviews were a bit negative. I'm glad to say I ignored the critics - this book was amazing. It's another rollercoaster ride though time, space, regret and vengeance. OK, there are some challenging ideas about our relevance to 'time' and 'memory', and for sure there are parallels with 'Dark Matter', but this is unique enough to keep you guessing, and the overall storyline is somehow mad and totally convincing at the same time.I really like Blake Crouch's attention to small details - descriptions of falling into stuff, and memories about trivia that I really equate with. And I disagree that there is too much repetition of scenarios. The whole idea of revisiting situations and attempting to put things right demands that. The whole idea of revisiting situations and attempting to put things right demands that.OK. I found it difficult to follow the constantly changing datelines of chapters when reading this on a Kindle on the U-Bahn (it's not so easy to flick back through the pages, right?) and there were some slightly confusing junctures earlier on in the book, but I soon got into the flow of this book during my commute. Still - I would recommend reading this book in as short a timeframe as possible, so you can easily follow the shifting decades and narratives.While the underlying principle of this book is thankfully impossible, the nihilistic consequences of the technology described by Crouch are totally believable, and for that reason, I give this book a big thumbs up. Nice one!
